description: From Middle English salve, from Old English sealf, from Proto-West Germanic *salbu, from Proto-Germanic *salbō, from Proto-Indo-European *solp-éh₂, from *selp- (“salve, ointment”).

entries.meaning: An ointment, cream, or balm with soothing, healing, or calming effects.
Any remedy or action that soothes or heals.

description: From Old English sealfian, from Proto-West Germanic *salbōn, from Proto-Germanic *salbōną, from *salbō (whence salve (noun)).

verbs.description: salve (third-person singular simple present salves, present participle salving, simple past and past participle salved)

entries.meaning: To heal by applications or medicaments; to apply salve to; to anoint.
To heal; to remedy; to cure; to make good.

verbs.description: salve (third-person singular simple present salves, present participle salving, simple past and past participle salved)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, astronomy) To save (the appearances or the phenomena); to explain (a celestial phenomenon); to account for (the apparent motions of the celestial bodies).
(obsolete) To resolve (a difficulty); to refute (an objection); to harmonize (an apparent contradiction).
examples: He which should hold it more rational to make the whole Universe move, and thereby to salve the Earths mobility, is more unreasonable....

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To explain away; to mitigate; to excuse.

verbs.description: salve (third-person singular simple present salves, present participle salving, simple past and past participle salved)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To say “salve” to; to greet; to salute.
